meanings.def: to go across; to pass or stretch from one side to the other
examples: As soon as traffic slowed down enough to safely cross, I started walking.
cross over I waved and she crossed over (= crossed the road towards me).
cross (over) from … He crossed over from the other side of the road.
cross (over) from… to/into… We crossed from Dover to Calais.
cross (over) to/into… She crossed to the other side of the room.
cross something to cross the road/street
to cross the sea/mountains
to cross France by train
The bridge crosses the River Dee.
He was caught trying to cross the border illegally.
More than 150 000 people crossed the bridge that day.
A look of annoyance crossed her face.
They crossed the finishing line together (= in a race).
cross over something He crossed over the road and joined me.
Children must be taught to cross the road safely.
Let's cross over now while the road is clear.
They crossed from the States into Canada.
They were arrested trying to cross the border.
We crossed over the river into Sweden.
A bridge crosses the river a few miles upstream.
It was the first time she had crossed the Atlantic.
The ferry crosses from Portsmouth to Santander.
They crossed the mountains into Spain.
You have to be really careful crossing the road here.

meanings.def: to pass across each other
examples: The roads cross just outside the town.
cross over The straps cross over at the back and are tied at the waist.
Our letters must have crossed in the mail (= each was sent before the other was received).

meanings.def: to put or place something across or over something else
examples: to cross your arms/legs (= place one arm or leg over the other)
She sat with her legs crossed.
a flag with a design of two crossed keys

meanings.def: to oppose somebody or speak against them or their plans or wishes
examples: She's really nice until you cross her.
(literary) He had been crossed in love (= the person he loved was not faithful to him).

meanings.def: to make two different types of animal breed (= produce young) together; to mix two types of plant to form a new one
examples: A mule is the product of a horse crossed with a donkey.
(figurative) He behaved like an army officer crossed with a professor.

meanings.def: to kick or pass a ball to the side across the field
examples: Sissoko crossed from the left.
cross something He could not get to the line to cross the ball.

meanings.def: to draw a line across something
examples: to cross your t’s (= the letters in writing)

meanings.def: to make the sign of the cross (= the Christian symbol) on your chest
to do something that is not considered to be acceptable behaviour
examples: He crossed the line by making details of their very private conversation public.

meanings.def: to hope that your plans will be successful (sometimes putting one finger across another as a sign of hoping for good luck)
examples: I'm crossing my fingers that my proposal will be accepted.
Keep your fingers crossed!

meanings.def: used to emphasize that you are telling the truth or will do what you promise
examples: I saw him do it—cross my heart.

meanings.def: to come into your mind
examples: It never crossed my mind that she might lose (= I was sure that she would win).
The thought never crossed my mind!

meanings.def: to give somebody money so that they will do you a favour, especially tell your fortune
if somebody crosses somebody’s path or their paths cross, they meet by chance
examples: I hope I never cross her path again.
Our paths were to cross again many years later.

meanings.def: to fight or argue with somebody
to worry about a problem when it actually happens and not before
to pay attention to the small details when you are finishing a task
to become confused about what somebody has said to you so that you think they meant something else
examples: We seem to have got our wires crossed. I thought you were coming on Tuesday.

idioms.def: to do something that is not considered to be acceptable behaviour
examples: He crossed the line by making details of their very private conversation public.

idioms.def: to hope that your plans will be successful (sometimes putting one finger across another as a sign of hoping for good luck)
examples: I'm crossing my fingers that my proposal will be accepted.
Keep your fingers crossed!

idioms.idiom: cross my heart (and hope to die)
idioms.def: used to emphasize that you are telling the truth or will do what you promise
examples: I saw him do it—cross my heart.
It never crossed my mind that she might lose (= I was sure that she would win).
The thought never crossed my mind!

idioms.def: to give somebody money so that they will do you a favour, especially tell your fortune

idioms.idiom: cross somebody’s path | people’s paths cross
idioms.def: if somebody crosses somebody’s path or their paths cross, they meet by chance
examples: I hope I never cross her path again.
Our paths were to cross again many years later.

idioms.def: to fight or argue with somebody

idioms.idiom: cross that bridge when you come to it
idioms.def: to worry about a problem when it actually happens and not before

idioms.idiom: dot your i’s and cross your t’s
idioms.def: to pay attention to the small details when you are finishing a task
to become confused about what somebody has said to you so that you think they meant something else
examples: We seem to have got our wires crossed. I thought you were coming on Tuesday.

meanings.def: a mark or an object formed by two lines crossing each other (X or +); the mark (X) is often used on paper to show something
examples: I've put a cross on the map to show where the hotel is.
Put a tick if the answer is correct and a cross if it's wrong.
Sign your name on the form where I've put a cross.
Those who could not write signed with a cross.
Put a cross beside the name of the candidate you wish to vote for.

meanings.def: a long straight piece of wood with one end in the ground and a shorter piece joined across it from side to side near the top. In the past people were hung on crosses and left to die as a punishment.
the cross that Jesus Christ died on, used as a symbol of Christianity
examples: The priest blessed her, and made the sign of the cross over her.
a painting of Christ on the cross

meanings.def: an object, a design, a piece of jewellery, etc. in the shape of a cross, used as a symbol of Christianity
examples: She wore a small gold cross on a chain around her neck.
The grave was marked with a stone cross.

meanings.def: a small decoration in the shape of a cross that is given to somebody as an honour for doing something very brave
examples: He was awarded the Military Cross.
He was awarded the Victoria Cross for bravery.

meanings.def: a mixture of two different things, breeds (= types) of animal, etc.
examples: The play was a cross between a farce and a tragedy.
A mule is a cross between a horse and a donkey.

meanings.def: a kick or hit of the ball across the field rather than up or down it
examples: Webster's low cross was fired into the net by Varney.
a deep cross from Sterling

meanings.def: to have a difficult problem that makes you worried or unhappy but that you have to deal with
examples: We all have our crosses to bear.

idioms.def: to have a difficult problem that makes you worried or unhappy but that you have to deal with
examples: We all have our crosses to bear.

meanings.def: annoyed or quite angry
examples: I was cross with him for being late.
Please don't get cross. Let me explain.
Please don’t be angry with me.
Thousands of angry demonstrators filled the square.
He got mad and walked out.
She’s mad at me for being late.
She was very indignant at the way she had been treated.
I was quite cross with him for being late.
irate customers
an irate letter
I'm going to get very cross before long.
It really makes me cross to see people dropping litter in the street.
She was quite cross with him for being late.
She was very cross at the way she'd been treated.
If you don't do as you're told I shall get very cross.
She was so cross she couldn't speak.

meanings.def: involving movement or action from one thing to another or between two things
examples: cross-Channel ferries
cross-fertilize
crossfire
